This task order is part of the DID programme's Covid-19 response portfolio. The DID Covid-19 response and recovery coordination platform was established with the vital mandate to coordinate the response while looking at opportunities for joint awareness and advocacy campaigning, sharing of resources, production of evidence-based disability inclusive learning and development of sharing mechanisms to influence policies, promoting research uptake and coordinating disability-inclusive Covid-19 response.

title.narrative: DID TO13 - Strengthening systems for the enrolment, retention and support of children with disabilities at primary level of mainstream education in Bangladesh - Phase 1

description.narrative:
This task order has been developed by adapting the original planning for an inclusive education task order in Bangladesh focussing on children with disabilities out of primary school - especially those with severe and multiple disabilities. Acknowledging the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and the school closures for a big part of the school year 2020 the approach for 2021 is adapted to support the return of children with disabilities into school who were previously enrolled, during the COVID-19 recovery in the education sector in Bangladesh.
While adapting to the new environment in the education sector, the initial plan for 2021 to identify children who have never been enrolled due to severe and multiple disabilities and start work with families and communities to promote their enrolment in schools in 2022 will still go ahead. Experience from consortium partners’ inclusive education projects in other countries has showed that in the current scenario it is likely that children who have never been enrolled at school will likely experience increased levels of exclusion and be the last ones to go to schools until the situation normalises. In this task order options to address this, including a shift of focus towards a community-based model of support and education at home, will be explored, to inform the strategy for phase 2 from 2022 onwards.
Within this task order the groundwork of the cooperation with the PENDA programme on the planned impact evaluation - focussing on phase 2 from January 2022 onwards - will be laid.

description.narrative: Around one-fifth of young people worldwide were not in employment, education or training, prior to COVID-19. The Skills for Prosperity Programme tackles this global challenge by supporting education and skills systems across nine middle income countries in South East Asia, Latin America and Africa. Working hand in hand with national governments, industry and the education and skills sector, Skills for Prosperity seeks to improve the life chances of marginalised groups, including young people and women. It aims to do this by equipping them with skills fit for the future, thereby helping to improve the prosperity of individuals, communities and economies. This is a flagship global skills programme for the UK government.

title.narrative: Education Research in Conflict and Protracted Crisis (ERICC)

description.narrative: To strengthen policies and programming for education in conflict and protracted crisis. This programme will improve learning outcomes of the most marginalised children. It responds to a demand for rigorous, policy-relevant research in six focal countries on "what works" to deliver education in these contexts. The UK will work with partners to disseminate evidence and promote uptake, and provide technical expertise and operational support to DFID country offices. It is expected that initial technical call-down support for governments will have a focus on Covid-19. This programme will have a focus on equity, and directly supports the manifesto commitment on girls' education,

title.narrative: Bangladesh - Rohingya Response and National Resilience Programme (RRNRP)

description.narrative: To improve protection and quality of humanitarian assistance for the Rohingya population living in refugee camps in southern Bangladesh, so that they can live full and meaningful lives. This to be done peacefully living alongside host communities, for whom the impacts of the crisis need to be reduced and development opportunities provided. The programme marks a shift in FCDO’s (Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office) response to the crisis by providing longer term, predictable support to address the needs of both refugees and host communities. Whilst the focus will be on sustaining and improving the humanitarian operation through provision of quality basic services, there will be a specific focus on stimulating the economy, rehabilitating the environment, and promoting stability for both populations’ benefit. The programme aim to support COVID-19 and early emergency recovery support for national resilience by providing support to the national COVID-19 and disaster response.

title.narrative: Getting children ready to learn and thrive - Research into implementing effective and quality Early Childhood Development at scale

description.narrative: The THRIVE Early Childhood Development research programme will deliver research on how to implement effective ECD interventions at scale in LMICs. Through an innovative model of research co-designed and aligned to DFID country programmes, THRIVE will support four DFID bilateral programmes to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of ECD interventions emdedded in their education and human development programmes, and commission globally-relevant research into optimal ECD service delivery and scale up strategies. Through the proposed COVID-19 pivot, the programme will generate real time evidence on impact of Covid-19 on young children's learning and development, and test at scale innovation on approaches to mitigate the crisis of learning and care. This programme directly responds to the manifesto commitment on girls' education.

description.narrative: This programme will secure UK leadership to produce global goods in education, catalyse mulitlateral, bilateral and philanthropic spend to address learning poverty, and convene global and national policy reform events across 27 DFID countries. Funding will support research projects which respond to the urgent need to understand how to bring girls back into the classroom following Covid-19 school closures, and informs systems change to ensure all children can learn once they return to school. This programme directly responds to the manifesto commitment on girls' education.

receiver-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

description.narrative: Provide rapid support to the healthcare response to Covid-19, delivering much needed medical equipment and supporting public communications through WHO delivery. Assistance would be directed towards quickly stabilising the fragile healthcare system - which was already overburdened and strained by an economic crisis - at a very crucial time. On top of the underlying pressures, the Government has said the crisis is overwhelming the system. This will be both humanitarian and preventive in nature. WHO assess a significant number of lives could be saved if a severe Covid-19 outbreak can be avoided through proper containment measures; it will also mitigate against secondary instability shocks (particularly amongst vulnerable communities such as Syrian and Palestinian refugees).

title.narrative: Hygiene, Handwashing & Behaviour Change Coalition for COVID 19 response programme

description.narrative: To develop an innovative partnership with Unilever to provide funding, that will be matched by the private sector, for a Unilever-led ‘Hygiene, Handwashing & Behaviour Change’ Coalition for Covid19. Under Unilever leadership, the coalition will bring together academia (e.g. London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine), INGOs (e.g. Oxfam) and delivery partners (e.g. GAVI) to deliver mass communications, product response and digital behaviour change programmes on the importance of hand and environmental hygiene. This will build on recent investments Unilever has made in response to Covid19 and will allow scale up across multiple countries.
